intro: Alpinia missionis, commonly known as the Mission Island ginger, is a flowering plant native to the tropical regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Zingiberaceae family, which includes other economically important plants like ginger and turmeric. The plant is characterized by its tall, leafy stems and clusters of fragrant, pale yellow to orange flowers. Its rhizomes are often used in traditional medicine for their purported anti-inflammatory and digestive properties. Alpinia missionis thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in forest understories.
